natural problem: What is the remainder when $5^{207}$ is divided by 7?
natural solution: We try finding the remainders when increasing powers of 5 are divided by 7. \begin{align} 5^1\div 7 &\text{ leaves a remainder of } 5.\\ 5^2\div 7 &\text{ leaves a remainder of } 4.\\ 5^3\div 7&\text{ leaves a remainder of } 6.\\

5^4\div 7&\text{ leaves a remainder of } 2.\\ 5^5\div 7&\text{ leaves a remainder of }3.\\ 5^6\div 7 &\text{ leaves a remainder of }1.\\ 5^7\div 7 &\text{ leaves a remainder of } 5.\\ 5^8\div 7 &\text{ leaves a remainder of }4.
\end{align} $$\vdots$$ The remainders repeat after every 6 powers of 5.
So we look for the remainder when 207 is divided by 6, which leaves a remainder of 3.

We could use long division, but notice that 207 is a multiple of 3 (digits sum to 9, which is a multiple of 3) but is not a multiple of 2. That means 207 is not divisible by 6 and must be exactly 3 more than a multiple of 6.
So the remainder for $5^{207}$ when divided by 7 is the same as the remainder when $5^3$ is divided by 7, which is $\boxed{6}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: int
assumes h0 : "x = 5^207 mod 7"
shows  "x = 6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $5^{207}$ is divided by 7? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 We try finding the remainders when increasing powers of 5 are divided by 7. \begin{align} 5^1\div 7 &\text{ leaves a remainder of } 5.\\ 5^2\div 7 &\text{ leaves a remainder of } 4.\\ 5^3\div 7&\text{ leaves a remainder of } 6.\\
 5^4\div 7&\text{ leaves a remainder of } 2.\\ 5^5\div 7&\text{ leaves a remainder of }3.\\ 5^6\div 7 &\text{ leaves a remainder of }1.\\ 5^7\div 7 &\text{ leaves a remainder of } 5.\\ 5^8\div 7 &\text{ leaves a remainder of }4.
 \end{align} $$\vdots$$ The remainders repeat after every 6 powers of 5.
 So we look for the remainder when 207 is divided by 6, which leaves a remainder of 3.
 We could use long division, but notice that 207 is a multiple of 3 (digits sum to 9, which is a multiple of 3) but is not a multiple of 2. That means 207 is not divisible by 6 and must be exactly 3 more than a multiple of 6.
 So the remainder for $5^{207}$ when divided by 7 is the same as the remainder when $5^3$ is divided by 7, which is $\boxed{6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: int
assumes h0 : "x = 5^207 mod 7"
shows  "x = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the remainder when $5^{207}$ is divided by 7. The final answer is 6.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: int and P :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a. P a = 5^207"
and h1 : "P a mod 7 = b"
shows  "b = 6"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $5^{207}$ is divided by 7? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 We try finding the remainders when increasing powers of 5 are divided by 7. \begin{align} 5^1\div 7 &\text{ leaves a remainder of } 5.\\ 5^2\div 7 &\text{ leaves a remainder of } 4.\\ 5^3\div 7&\text{ leaves a remainder of } 6.\\
 5^4\div 7&\text{ leaves a remainder of } 2.\\ 5^5\div 7&\text{ leaves a remainder of }3.\\ 5^6\div 7 &\text{ leaves a remainder of }1.\\ 5^7\div 7 &\text{ leaves a remainder of } 5.\\ 5^8\div 7 &\text{ leaves a remainder of }4.
 \end{align} $$\vdots$$ The remainders repeat after every 6 powers of 5.
 So we look for the remainder when 207 is divided by 6, which leaves a remainder of 3.
 We could use long division, but notice that 207 is a multiple of 3 (digits sum to 9, which is a multiple of 3) but is not a multiple of 2. That means 207 is not divisible by 6 and must be exactly 3 more than a multiple of 6.
 So the remainder for $5^{207}$ when divided by 7 is the same as the remainder when $5^3$ is divided by 7, which is $\boxed{6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: int and P :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a. P a = 5^207"
and h1 : "P a mod 7 = b"
shows  "b = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "p n = 5 ^ n mod 7"
shows  "p 207 = 6"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $5^{207}$ is divided by 7? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 We try finding the remainders when increasing powers of 5 are divided by 7. \begin{align} 5^1\div 7 &\text{ leaves a remainder of } 5.\\ 5^2\div 7 &\text{ leaves a remainder of } 4.\\ 5^3\div 7&\text{ leaves a remainder of } 6.\\

 We could use long division, but notice that 207 is a multiple of 3 (digits sum to 9, which is a multiple of 3) but is not a multiple of 2. That means 207 is not divisible by 6 and must be exactly 3 more than a multiple of 6.
 So the remainder for $5^{207}$ when divided by 7 is the same as the remainder when $5^3$ is divided by 7, which is $\boxed{6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "p n = 5 ^ n mod 7"
shows  "p 207 = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
